abstract_summ: The methodology compares how the observed positive case rate vary with changes in the size of the tested population, and applies this gradient to infer total population infection rates.Background: Public health efforts to determine population infection rates from coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) have been hampered by limitations in testing capabilities and the large shares of mild and asymptomatic cases.We developed a methodology that corrects observed positive test rates for non-random sampling to estimate population infection rates across U.S. states from March 31 to April 7.With increasingly available high frequency data on COVID-19 testing, our methodology could be used to estimate population infection rates for a range of countries and subnational districts.Methods We adapted a sample selection model that corrects for non-random testing to estimate population infection rates.
title_summ: Estimating COVID-19 Prevalence in the United States: A Sample Selection Model ApproachImpact of virus testing on COVID-19 case fatality rate: estimate using a fixed-effects modelEstimating the Early Outbreak Cumulative Incidence of COVID-19 in the United States: Three Complementary ApproachesA comparative analysis between strategies to face COVID-19 pandemic.Testing for tracing or testing just for treating?
